docs.lead_paragraph: In the Democratic Caucus of the Washington State Senate, male legislators, already outnumbered by their female counterparts 18 to 9, have formed a Last Man's Club, betting among themselves, with a touch of nervous bonhomie, on who will be the final one left before all the caucus members are women. The men also shrug good-naturedly when asked whatever happened to their posh, marble-lined bathroom in the State Capitol. The women took it over last year, and the men were re-assigned to a decidedly less ornate lavatory, with fewer stalls, that had been the ladies' room.

headline.main: Record for Women in Washington Legislature

docs.abstract: Women constitute 40.8 percent of Washington State's Legislature, highest percentage of women in any state legislature in nation's history; are among more potent symbols of electoral tide that has brought record numbers into public office in 1999, notably in increasingly important state legislature; make up 36.5 percent of Nevada Legislature, 35.6 percent of Arizona's, 33 percent of Colorado's and 32.7 percent of Kansas'; photo; chart; map (M)
docs.snippet: In the Democratic Caucus of the Washington State Senate, male legislators, already outnumbered by their female counterparts 18 to 9, have formed a Last Man's Club, betting among themselves, with a touch of nervous bonhomie, on who will be the final...

docs.lead_paragraph: As doctors grow angrier over managed care, the effort to unionize physicians has sharply accelerated in recent months, with more and more unions scrambling to recruit them and thousands of doctors signing up. More than half a dozen unions -- including the International Association of Machinists and the American Federation of Teachers -- are competing for them. Worried about being left out, even the American Medical Association, long opposed to doctors' forming unions, is setting up a unit to do collective bargaining.

headline.main: Angered by H.M.O.'s Treatment, More Doctors Are Joining Unions

docs.abstract: Growing numbers of doctors are joining unions, hoping to strengthen their position when dealing with managed care companies; even American Medical Assn, which long opposed doctors' unions, is setting up unit to do collective bargaining; most union activity is among salaried staff doctors at hospitals, where unions negotiate contracts covering doctors' wages, hours and working conditions; doctors in private practice who join unions seek more expertise and power when they negotiate with HMO's; HMO's claim doctors are independent contractors and therefore not allowed to unionize; hospitals fear unionization will lower their profits; Justice Dept has opposed one organizing effort on antitrust grounds; union trend expected to gain further momentum because 80 percent of recent medical school graduates are taking salaried jobs with HMO's, clinics or hospitals; photos (M)
docs.snippet: As doctors grow angrier over managed care, the effort to unionize physicians has sharply accelerated in recent months, with more and more unions scrambling to recruit them and thousands of doctors signing up.    More than half a dozen unions --...

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT CLINTON'S budget includes dozens of new spending programs. It also includes dozens of new tax credits and other subsidies. Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, mockingly declares ''the era of Big Government is back'' three years after Mr. Clinton declared it over. But charges of extravagance are unconvincing. Even if Congress passed Mr. Clinton's entire plan, the relative size of the Federal Government would continue to shrink, budget analysts point out. Robert Greenstein of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research organization, estimates Government spending, while continuing to grow modestly in absolute dollars, will fall by 2004 to about 18.5 percent of total economic output. That level, down from 19.7 percent today, would be the lowest in 34 years.

headline.main: Economic Scene; Clinton's budget plan on social needs will barely make a dent.

docs.abstract: Economic Scene column on Pres Clinton's budget that includes dozens of new spending programs; says charges of extravagance are unconvincing; holds analysts believe that even if Congress passed Clinton's entire plan, relative size of Federal Government would continue to shrink; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: PRESIDENT CLINTON'S budget includes dozens of new spending programs. It also includes dozens of new tax credits and other subsidies. Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, mockingly declares ''the era of Big Government is back'' three years...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten months ago, when Silverstein Properties and the Morgan Stanley Real Estate Fund bought the 51-story, 1.2 million-square-foot office building at 140 Broadway from the Helmsley organization for $191 million -- or almost $160 a square foot -- the building was only 59 percent occupied and needed a $60 million renovation. But it was also one of the few trophy properties available downtown, and one of the few with large blocks of contiguous vacant space. Now, the extensive renovation of the 1967 building is under way and new leases for more than 150,000 square feet of space have been signed -- some of them, on the higher floors, for average annual rents in the mid- to high $40's a square foot, which brokers say are among the highest seen downtown in recent months. And, buoyed by an upturn in the lower Manhattan market and the scarcity of top-of-the-line Class A space downtown, the landlord says he is confident of filling the building.

headline.main: Downtown Tower Gets a New Look

docs.abstract: Silverstein Properties, which bought lower Manhattan office building with Morgan Stanley Real Estate Fund last year, has begun extensive renovation, signed new leases and expects to fill all vacant space; improvement in downtown market noted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: From the outset the deal seemed like one of those win-win-win situations that politicians love. Nassau County would save millions in health care costs; a company whose officials were friendly with and supported Republican politicians would get the nearly half-billion-dollar contract, and some well-connected businessmen would profit, too. Now that dream deal has morphed into a financial nightmare. The county comptroller has found that cost overruns in the health plan exceed $34 million and may reach $50 million by the time all claims are counted.

headline.main: Nassau G.O.P. Sees Failed Deal On Insurance Become a Peril

docs.abstract: Republicans in Nassau County, NY, where patronage and insider deals have long been fixture of politics, fear political impact of big cost overruns in health care plan for county employees; Robert J McDonald, then deputy county executive, was main architect of switch to plan run by Benefit Plan Administrators Inc, which guaranteed to save county $15 million; he has admitted getting $12,500 a month in consulting fees from William M Blake, Suffolk County Republican leader whose insurance agency underwrote deal and got large fees (M)
docs.snippet: From the outset the deal seemed like one of those win-win-win situations that politicians love. Nassau County would save millions in health care costs; a company whose officials were friendly with and supported Republican politicians would get the...

docs.lead_paragraph: In what New Jersey prosecutors said was the largest single group of defendants in a single state criminal case, 65 people were indicted today on charges that they conspired with a psychologist to defraud health insurers of $3.5 million for sham treatments of ''neurotic depression.'' The individuals charged were mostly school system workers -- ranging from a vice principal to a custodian -- in Newark, East Orange, Passaic, Hillside and Plainfield.
docs.abstract: Sixty-five people, mostly school system workers, are indicted for allegedly conspiring with psychologist, Carl Lichtman, to defraud about 35 different health insurers of $3.5 million for sham treatments of 'neurotic depression;' Lichtman, who has already pleaded guilty, allegedly gave patients kickbacks, but no treatment; another 112 people have also pleaded guilty, agreeing to give up school system jobs, make restitution and serve sentences of up to three years' probation; many of those indicted hold they were illegally suspended from jobs and were pulled into scheme in belief it was legitimate program (M)
docs.snippet: In what New Jersey prosecutors said was the largest single group of defendants in a single state criminal case, 65 people were indicted today on charges that they conspired with a psychologist to defraud health insurers of $3.5 million for sham...

docs.lead_paragraph: Last June, Takaharu Akimoto's boss politely and apologetically asked him to quit his job as a production manager at the Shoshiba Manufacturing Company, a midsized engine parts maker affiliated with the beleaguered Nissan Motor Company. ''I said to myself, 'Impossible!' '' Mr. Akimoto recalled. ''I told him I didn't want to quit, please let me stay longer.''

headline.main: In Japan, From a Lifetime Job to No Job at All

docs.abstract: Japanese accustomed to lifetime employment are shocked by layoffs stemming from deep economic woes; Japan's 4.1 percent unemployment rate strikes blow to country's self-image and to social contract that has kept public complacent and one party in power for decades; jobless battle shame and despair, as well as challenge of finding work, and humiliation is even flaring into rare public anger; Takaharu Akimoto recalls disbelief at being asked to resign, seven years short of retirement; he is among older, higher-paid workers with particular problems finding new jobs; photo; graph; Government is going to great lengths to keep jobless figures from rising, providing generous subsidies to companies to keep workers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday after investors, faced with uncertainty about the future course of interest rates, chose to take some profits in late trading. The afternoon selling choked off what had been a fairly broad-based advance. Still, the Nasdaq composite index rose to a new record.

headline.main: Nasdaq Has Another Record Day, While Dow Slips a Bit

docs.abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 13.13 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 9,345.70; Nasdaq composite index closes up 4.20 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to record 2,510.09; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slips 6.64 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,273; graph; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday after investors, faced with uncertainty about the future course of interest rates, chose to take some profits in late trading.    The afternoon selling choked off what had been a fairly broad-based advance....

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton, hailing a new era of fiscal abundance, today proposed a budget for 2000 that he called a ''progressive but prudent path to our future,'' but Republicans immediately attacked it as a throwback to an earlier age of liberal largesse. The President said his $1.77 trillion plan would insure the solvency of Social Security and Medicare for decades while paying for billions of dollars in programs for schools, cities, families, the environment and the military.

headline.main: Clinton Offers His Budget, and the Battle Begins
headline.kicker: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE OVERVIEW

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, hailing new era of fiscal abundance, proposes $1.77 trillion budget for 2000 that he calls 'progressive but prudent path to our future'; says budget would insure solvency of Social Security and Medicare for decades while paying billions for social programs, education, environment and military; paints vision of future in which economy is insulated against domestic recession or foreign shocks by setting aside large portion of $4.47 trillion in projected surpluses over next 15 years to reduce Federal debt from current level of 44 percent of gross domestic product to just 7 percent in 2014, lowest level of public debt since 1917; Republicans score proposals as throwback to earlier age of liberal largesse; accuse Clinton of shortchanging taxpayers by devoting billions in surplus Govt revenues to new programs rather than tax cuts; comments by House Speaker Dennis Hastert noted; Clinton's budget proposals discussed; photo; charts; graph (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton, hailing a new era of fiscal abundance, today proposed a budget for 2000 that he called a ''progressive but prudent path to our future,'' but Republicans immediately attacked it as a throwback to an earlier age of liberal largesse. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The AXA Group of France, one of the world's largest insurance and financial services companies, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Guardian Royal Exchange P.L.C. for $5.68 billion, greatly expanding its auto and homeowner business in Britain. The deal, through its Sun Life and Provincial Holdings subsidiary, will make AXA No. 3 in Britain's property and casualty insurance business, up from 10th. It will also fortify its No. 3 ranking in life insurance and give it the No. 2 position in health insurance, a new field for AXA in Britain.

headline.main: AXA of France to Buy Guardian of Britain

docs.abstract: AXA Group of France to acquire Guardian Royal Exchange PLC for $5.68 billion; deal, through its Sun Life and Provincial Holdings subsidiary, will make AXA number 3 in Britain's property and casualty insurance business; deal gives AXA a corporate insurance unit in Germany to bolster its subsidiary there; as part of deal, AXA will sell Guardian Royal's property-casualty business in US to Liberty Mutual Group in Boston for $1.47 billion (M)
